review_title: Overall, a great place to work... but still recovering from painful couple of years
pros: Great people, generally very friendly. Small enough that you will know people by first name, even though they work across campus from you. Large enough to feel like an authentic university. Benefits are great, although I've had better in a corporate position. President Mason is agile enough to be an effective president (read: politicking with fundraisers and avoiding making promises she cannot keep), yet warm and genuine enough to endear herself to most employees. She does seem to truly care about employees.
cons:
The University, being in a small town, does have a tendency to hire within. While criticism for that is deserved, it happens because people from large cities often come in, hate the small size, and use a position here as a resume builder... and off they go, a year or five later, to a bigger city again. Sometimes this has its own frustrations...like spending all of your time replacing and training people,  which is why you can end up with internal promotions as often as not. However, I wouldn't discourage outsiders from applying; I would just advise that you make sure you have solid reason to want to live in Hays, KS. 

 (Former) President Mirta Martin was divisive. You will see her referenced by others on here; she made history as the first female and first Hispanic president. At first, I was thrilled. She has an inspiring story, was a Cuban refugee as a child, etc. However, she became a tyrant. She literally *yelled* at faculty and staff in "town hall" type meetings, wherein she rolled out her suggestions for a broad "re-engineering" process. She brought in cronies from Virginia who were unqualified and underqualifed, and promoted them to VP and AVP positions, sometimes going so far as to create those positions for them. In one case, she even directed a search committee to rewrite a job posting, to fit a resume of a friend better.  So, yes, she was eventually forced to resign. And many don't understand why, because they bought what she was selling or because they weren't in those meetings.  She did do some great things while she was here (See the Hispanic College Institute), but her demeanor as a tyrant, her corruption at bringing in cronies who had no experience in the roles she placed them in, and her lack of boundaries and inappropriate ways of interacting with people (She hugged faculty and staff going into meetings- seriously, all of us, and we did NOT welcome these hugs), rubbing the shoulders of football players at games, and letting several of her fore-mentioned cronies live in the basement of the president's residence, infuriated many faculty and staff. Worse of all, she would have absolutely NO criticism, she would never listen to those who disagree with her. So, there really was no other choice.

What this means today (Spring 2019) is that things are about a million times better, but there is still some healing going on. Fortunately, the new president (Tisa Mason) spent time at FHSU previously, as a VP.  This has provided for a smooth transition, so that she can focus on making things better and looking forward. She's been here for two years now, and things are much better. Best of all, it seems like the president actually cares about others' opinion. I don't agree with everything she does, but I generally can see why she is doing it, and I do still feel like my opinion is generally valued.

Hays is a small town- about 18,000 people. There are a few great restaurants and pubs (Look up Gella's/Lb Brewing), an active arts scene, and great rec programs for kids... but it's not going to compare to what you might have experienced, if you've lived in larger cities. The trade-off is that you might actually know the parents of your kids' friends.

pros:
They have a great benefits package, healthcare, insurance, etc. After 1 year of employment you are eligible for the 401K which I believe has an 8% match on a 6% contribution, and you become eligible for tuition assistance (50% for any classes you enroll in after becoming eligible for the benefit).

The job duties and responsibilities for an Administrative Associate or Assistant can vary from department to department. The core duties are not typically overwhelming. The offices you work with frequently for core duties, such as Administration and Finance and Accounts Payable are very helpful, great folks. There are a lot of great staff at the university in every department and office.
cons:
Just as I exited the university (4/17), they got not budgetary/payroll/forms approval software, called WorkDay. I went though the training and thought it was more user friendly than its outdated predecessor software, but from what I gather from speaking to former colleagues a couple months later, they are still working out some bugs and it doesn't seem to be as user friendly as I suspected it would be. AA's use this software almost daily. I trust these bugs will get worked out over time and with continued use. 

Unfortunately for many higher education institutions in Kansas, there as been issues with the most upper administration at the university. I will not get deep into the politics of the matter, but I will say I did not agree with how the former University President was removed from her position, or how some of the faculty and staff handled trying to remove her from that position. I don't believe that lack of professional behavior would be reflected in relationships between professors/administrators and support staff like AAs. I communicated with a lot of different departments and everyone at the university is very pleasant to work with an very helpful.
